subject: Curlin (Race Horse)
Horse Racing
Frauds and Swindling
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury issued new indictments against two part-owners of the 2007 Horse of the Year Curlin. The owners, William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr., are accused of defrauding clients of $94 million after winning a settlement from manufacturers of the diet drug fen-phen. A jury could not reach a verdict against them in July during a trial on charges of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. The new indictment charges the men with eight counts of wire fraud. Cunningham’s lawyer, Steven Dobson, questioned whether the newest indictment was a result of vindictiveness from prosecutors who failed to get a conviction. The two defendants bought Curlin, winner of last year’s Preakness, in 2004 before selling an 80 percent interest.
